intro: Rorippa williamsii, commonly known as the Williams' water-cress, is a small, aquatic or semi-aquatic flowering plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of ponds and streams, preferring moist, nutrient-rich soils. The plant has slender, branching stems that are often submerged or partially submerged, with small, alternate leaves that are usually linear to ovate in shape. Its flowers are white or pale yellow, arranged in racemes, and are typically pollinated by insects. Rorippa williamsii is characterized by its rapid growth and ability to thrive in disturbed aquatic environments.
